channel.title: BBC News - Entertainment & Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Lily Cole: Model apologises for posing in a burka on Instagram
item.description: The model and activist posted a picture of herself in a burka as a way to "embrace diversity".

item.title: Selma Blair: Actress says she's in remission from multiple sclerosis
item.description: The Cruel Intentions star says her multiple sclerosis has improved thanks to a stem cell transplant.

item.title: Bob Dylan denies sexually abusing girl in 1965
item.description: A woman says the US singer-songwriter abused her when she was 12 - a claim he says is untrue.

item.title: Line of Duty stars to go head-to-head at National Television Awards
item.description: Vicky McClure, Adrian Dunbar and Martin Compston are nominated for the National Television Awards.

item.title: Eurovision singer James Newman wins copyright case over Rudimental hit
item.description: James Newman was sued over a hit song he wrote before coming last at this year's song contest.

item.title: New powers sought to stop illegal ticket resales
item.description: The UK's competition watchdog is calling for stronger laws to act quickly against touts.

item.title: Huw Edwards considering his future at BBC News at Ten
item.description: The journalist finds nightly news "taxing" and says it's "fair" viewers see a change in presenters.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Team GB given star-studded homecoming
item.description: Athletes attended a concert at London's SSE Arena, Wembley, to mark their return from Tokyo.

item.title: The Beatles: Aphrodite statue from historic gig being auctioned
item.description: The Aphrodite statue was used in The Beatles set in the first live satellite broadcast in 1967.

item.title: Banksy: A guide to his 'Great British Spraycation'
item.description: New murals that have appeared on England's east coast are confirmed as the work of the elusive artist.

item.title: Noel Gallagher: Photographer captures Oasis star's years on tour
item.description: Sharon Latham travelled the world with Noel Gallagher after she joked about photographing his band.

item.title: Shetland’s biggest gig – the day Pulp flew in to Lerwick
item.description: At the height of their fame, the Britpop icons travelled to Lerwick to play a show for just 1,400 fans.

item.title: Coda: 'Deafness is not a costume you can put on,' says film director
item.description: The maker of the film Coda says being authentic to the story of child with deaf parents was vital.

item.title: Nick Grimshaw: 'I'm leaving Radio 1 in a leap of faith'
item.description: The legendary presenter reflects on leaving BBC Radio 1 after 14 years.

item.title: Bloodstock: Heavy metal fans emotional at festival's return
item.description: Last year's edition had to take place online, but head-bangers are enjoying the big comeback.

item.title: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis poke fun at cleanliness debate
item.description: The Hollywood couple caused a stir last month by saying they didn't fully bathe their kids every day.

item.title: Lily Allen on feeling like theatre's 'village idiot'
item.description: The singer is temporarily pausing her successful music career to star in a brand new play 2:22.

item.title: Afghanistan: Female presenters back on Tolo News after Taliban takeover
item.description: Women had been noticeably absent from major news outlets after the Taliban took control of Afghanistan.

item.title: From a Manchester council estate to ballet dancing in Swan Lake
item.description: Isaac Bowry is from a Manchester council estate and wants to show that "dancing is for everyone".

item.title: Adam Peaty: I'm going to be very uncomfortable on Strictly
item.description: The Olympic champion is the latest to be announced for the show.

item.title: Reading: Teacher gets stories published after 46 years
item.description: Keith Godwin used to make up stories for his pupils in the 1970s, now they have been published.

item.title: Kiwi Chow: The film-maker who took Hong Kong's protests to Cannes
item.description: Kiwi Chow's documentary was a surprise at the film festival - and it has a controversial title.

item.title: Virtual reality: 'There's no max, there's no limit!'
item.description: "There's no max, there's no limit" to virtual reality, so is it the future of live music?
